channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: After Day Care Massacre, Thailand Is Roiled With Grief
item.description: Anguished families were coming to terms with the loss of their young children as the nation pondered issues like gun violence and the widespread availability of deadly weapons.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee, Ryn Jirenuwat and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Andre Malerba for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners pray at the gates of the day care center at the Uthai Sawan subdistrict office on Friday in Nong Bua Lamphu, Thailand.

item.title: Russia Pummels South With Strikes as Zelensky Heralds Ukrainian Advances
item.description: Nearly 40 rockets hit the southern city of Nikopol, an official said, as Russian shelling has picked up in recent days.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: In Record Numbers, Venezuelans Risk a Deadly Trek to the U.S. Border
item.description: Two crises are converging at the perilous land bridge known as the Darién Gap: the economic and humanitarian disaster underway in South America, and the bitter fight over immigration policy in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize Is Awarded to Russian, Ukrainian and Belarusian Activists
item.description: The three laureates are Memorial, a rights group in Russia; the Center for Civil Liberties in Ukraine; and Ales Bialiatski, an activist jailed in Belarus.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Staff of the Center for Civil Liberties, a Ukrainian human rights organization, celebrating in their office in Kyiv on Friday. The other recipients of the Nobel Peace Prize were Ales Bialiatski, a human rights advocate from Belarus, and Memorial, a Russian human rights organization.

item.title: Ireland Opens Decades of Secret Records to Adoptees
item.description: Thousands of people are being promised new rights to information, a potentially momentous step in a country where unmarried mothers were pressured for decades to give up their babies.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shrine honoring children interred at a mother and baby home in Tuam, Ireland, from 1925 to 1961. A local historian traced hundreds of deaths there.

item.title: Europe’s Energy Crisis Exposes Old Fault Lines and New Power Dynamics
item.description: Smaller countries see Germany’s domestic largess to tackle spiraling energy costs as undermining the effort to lower fuel prices for the wider European Union.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Energy facilities at Wilhelmshaven, a German hub for liquefied natural gas imports. Critics say Germany should prioritize lowering the price of natural gas for the whole E.U., instead of maneuvering to secure more for itself.

item.title: China’s ‘Zero Covid’ Pursuit Causes Mayhem Ahead of Party Conclave
item.description: Tourists are stranded, residents confined at home. Covid flare-ups and the accompanying lockdowns are causing disruptions ahead of a key Chinese Communist Party meeting.
item.dc:creator: John Liu
item.media:description: Watching the annual flag-raising ceremony near Tiananmen Square in Beijing on Oct. 1. Covid infections have surged in part because of the country’s weeklong National Day holiday.

item.title: ‘They Are in a Panic’: Ukraine’s Troops Size Up the Enemy
item.description: Ukrainian soldiers are exulting in their smashing of Russian lines in the northeast. They engaged enemy troops up close, and gained confidence from it.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: Blunt Criticism of Russian Army Signals New Challenge for Putin
item.description: An official in a Russian-occupied region of Ukraine suggested Russia’s defense minister should shoot himself because of his army’s failings, an unusually blunt and public rebuke of Kremlin leadership.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Sergei K. Shoigu, the Russian defense minister, with President Vladimir V. Putin at a commemoration of the victory over Nazi Germany in May.

item.title: Major Mexican Government Hack Reveals Military Abuse and Spying
item.description: Hackers infiltrated the Mexican Defense Ministry, publishing millions of emails that detail the military’s growing influence over the civilian government.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the military on patrol in Celaya, Mexico.

item.title: Some Unlikely Dealers Are Selling Weapons to Ukraine
item.description: New brokers are cashing in as the Biden administration quietly encourages private weapons sales to Ukraine. Oversight is scant in these shadows.
item.dc:creator: Justin Scheck
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier with a rocket-propelled grenade launcher outside of Kharkiv in the early days of the war. Ukraine has turned to private arms deals to meet its needs.

item.title: Saskatchewan Mass Killings Were the Work of One Brother, Police Say
item.description: The police said Myles Sanderson had killed not just 10 people on an Indigenous reserve and in a nearby village, but also his brother, Damien, who was originally charged with murder.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vigil for the victims of the killings last month in Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

item.title: U.S. Forces Kill Senior ISIS Leaders in Syria Strike and Raid, Officials Say
item.description: A nighttime raid and a drone strike killed three men whose activities included recruiting fighters and plotting attacks, according to American and Syrian Kurdish officials.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad, Sangar Khaleel and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: U.S. forces in Syria in September.

item.title: A City in Nepal Finally Got Tap Water. After a Disaster It Was Gone.
item.description: A disaster that wiped out a decades-long project to bring pipe-borne water to Nepal’s capital shows the mismatch between slow-moving donor-financed efforts and rapid global warming.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Bhadra Sharma
item.media:credit: Uma Bista for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents south of Kathmandu collecting water at a traditional stone spout, which works only during the rainy season.

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize Winners Share a Past Shadowed by Russian Abuses
item.description: Democracy advocates from Belarus, Russia and Ukraine were jointly awarded the world’s most prestigious peace prize, an implicit condemnation of the Kremlin’s war in Ukraine and repression at home.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Megan Specia and Andrew Higgins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Freitas/NTB Scanpix, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A picture of the jailed Belarus rights activist Ales Bialiatski, one of this year’s Nobel Peace Prize winners, is placed next to previous laureates in the garden of the Nobel Institute in Oslo, Norway.

item.title: US Targets Businessmen and Companies in New North Korea Sanctions
item.description: The Biden administration is bracing for Kim Jong-un to carry out a nuclear test. It says North Korea has fired 41 ballistic missiles this year, including one over Japan.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: A screen showing images of North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, during a news update in Tokyo on Tuesday. North Korea’s missile launch prompted an alert in Japan that morning.

item.title: Fire Causes ‘Irreparable’ Damage to Easter Island Statues
item.description: The fire has burned more than 247 acres of the Pacific island, where hundreds of haunting monolithic statues, called moai, have stood for centuries.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Rapanui Municipality/Getty Images
item.media:description: Many ancient monolithic statues, called moai, have been damaged in a fire in Rapa Nui National Park on Easter Island.

item.title: White House Tightens Rules on Counterterrorism Drone Strikes
item.description: A classified new policy requires President Biden’s approval to add suspected terrorists to a kill list. The Trump administration had decentralized control over targeting decisions.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An Air Force Predator drone, right, returning from a mission in the Persian Gulf region in 2016. The new policy suggests that the United States intends to launch fewer drone strikes away from recognized war zones.

item.title: Memorial Shed Light on Russia’s Past and Current Repressions
item.description: Members of the group have paid for their work with their lives and their freedom.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Anton Troianovski
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Members of rights group Memorial hold a press conference in Moscow in November 2021.

item.title: Liverpool Will Host 2023 Eurovision Song Contest
item.description: The popular competition would have been held in Ukraine, which won this year’s event, but safety concerns sent it to Britain instead.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukraine earned the right to host next year’s event after winning this year’s contest in May, but it was ruled out by Eurovision organizers.

item.title: Putin’s 70th Birthday Is Hailed in Russia and Derided in Ukraine
item.description: Russian newspapers lauded Mr. Putin’s leadership, comparing him to Peter the Great and Leonid Brezhnev. Some Ukrainians said they hoped the birthday would be his last.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova and Megan Specia
item.media:description: A visitor stands next to Alexey Sergienko’s painting called “Putin with a Puppy,” presented on the eve of the 70th birthday of Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian president, in St. Petersburg on Thursday.

item.title: An Abortion Ban With Unexpected Consequences for Older Mothers
item.description: Older women are more likely to carry fetuses with genetic disorders that often can’t be detected until 15 weeks of pregnancy, beyond the limit set in a Senate proposal.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: Ashbey Beasley, in orange, a mother who found that her fetus had an anomaly after 16 weeks, confronted Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina as he unveiled his abortion bill last month.

item.title: Tropical Storm Julia Forms in the Caribbean
item.description: The storm, which was expected to reach hurricane strength over the weekend, was lashing the Guajira Peninsula in northern Colombia with heavy rain on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: A tropical depression in the southwestern Caribbean strengthened into Tropical Storm Julia on Friday.

item.title: Who Is Ales Bialiatski, the Belarusian Nobel Peace Prize Laureate?
item.description: Ales Bialiatski was part of a dissident group that helped lay the groundwork in the late Soviet period for a movement calling for the independence of Belarus.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Ales Bialiatski, a Belarusian rights activist, speaking at a Right Livelihood Award event in Stockholm in 2020.

item.title: In Ukraine, Sharing the Nobel Peace Prize Prompts Backlash
item.description: Some saw the decision to group a Ukrainian organization with human rights defenders from Russia and Belarus — two of the country’s aggressors — as an affront.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Distributing aid to civilians in the recently liberated city of Izium, in the eastern Kharkiv region of Ukraine, last week.

item.title: A Canadian Family Is Seeing the World Before Their Children’s Vision Falters
item.description: A Canadian family is on a yearlong journey across Asia and Africa because three of their four children have an eye condition that causes blindness.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: Ukraine’s Center for Civil Liberties Among 2022 Nobel Peace Prize Winners
item.description: While the invasion added greater urgency to their work, the group has been tracking disappearances and war crimes for years.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A protester among a group of Center for Civil Liberties activists and representatives of the L.G.B.T.Q. community outside the Cabinet of Ministers building in Kyiv in 2020.

item.title: The Power of Paxlovid
item.description: The underuse of Covid treatments is leading to many needless deaths.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: Memorial, a Nobel Peace Prize Winner, Has Been Targeted by Putin in Russia
item.description: The organization “is based on the notion that confronting past crimes is essential in preventing new ones,” the Norwegian Nobel Committee said.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A demonstrator with a sign reading “Hands off Memorial” protested outside Russia’s Supreme Court in December as the court deliberated whether or dissolve Memorial.

item.title: Brittany Higgins Takes the Stand
item.description: The first week of the high profile trial in Australia has highlighted some of the difficulties of prosecuting sexual assault cases.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Brittany Higgins arriving to give evidence in front of an ACT Supreme Court jury on the third day of the trial of her alleged rapist, Bruce Lehrmann, in Canberra, Australia, on Thursday.

item.title: His Mom Labored on a Winery Under Apartheid. Now, He Owns One.
item.description: Paul Siguqa grew up hating wineries because his mother toiled in their fields. But last year he opened the only fully Black-owned vineyard in Franschhoek, one of South Africa’s most prestigious wine towns.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Tommy Trenchard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paul Siguqa, owner of the Klein Goederust winery, inspecting a glass of his cabernet-merlot blend.

item.title: So You Want to Work Remotely: A Guide
item.description: As more employers offer flexibility, countries, travel brands and entrepreneurs are stepping in to make working from anywhere easier, with everything from special visas to work pods.
item.dc:creator: Nora Walsh

item.title: How Iranians in New York Are Helping the Protests Abroad
item.description: “It’s really been a very long process of suffering that has led to this moment,” one activist said.
item.dc:creator: Sasha von Oldershausen
item.media:credit: Ahmed Gaber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Earlier this week, a vigil took place at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn to show solidarity for protesters in Iran.

item.title: Thailand’s Gun Laws Have Loopholes for Soldiers and Police Officers
item.description: Such buyers can purchase firearms from the government with fewer checks than those for civilians.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, Muktita Suhartono and Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: A man entering a gun shop in Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand, in 2020.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Challenges for Vladimir Putin in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Sergei K. Shoigu, the Russian defense minister, with President Vladimir V. Putin at a commemoration of the victory over Nazi Germany in May.

item.title: Biden Warns of Nuclear ‘Armageddon’ After Putin’s Recent Threats
item.description: The president’s blunt warnings, highly unusual for an American president, were delivered informally to a group of Democratic donors in New York City.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and David E. Sanger

item.title: Biden’s Choice After OPEC Cuts: Woo Saudi Arabia, or Retaliate?
item.description: The announcement by the Saudi-led OPEC Plus energy cartel that it would slash oil production was widely seen in Washington as a stab in the back of President Biden.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: The Saudi-led OPEC Plus energy cartel announced that it would pump two million fewer barrels a day just weeks before the American midterm elections.

item.title: Russia Lashes Out in Ukraine, Raising Question of What’s Next
item.description: Facing battlefield setbacks and domestic criticism, the Kremlin has escalated its war, claiming ownership of a nuclear plant and launching more attacks on Ukrainian cities.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña, Carly Olson and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Ukrainian firefighters battled a blaze after a strike in Zaporizhzhia on Thursday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Mass Shooting in Thailand
item.description: Plus growing dissent in Russia and China’s debt diplomacy
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: People outside the child-care facility on Thursday where a mass shooting took place in northeastern Thailand.

item.title: Day-Care Massacre in Thailand Was Among the World’s Deadliest
item.description: The 36 victims included a 2-year-old child and a teacher who was eight months pregnant, the police said. They identified the gunman as a recently fired officer.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Muktita Suhartono, Sui-Lee Wee and Ryn Jirenuwat
item.media:description: Emergency workers carrying coffins with the bodies of victims outside a hospital in Udon Thani.

item.title: Ukraine Police Find Bodies of 534 Civilians in Recaptured Territory
item.description: The police have discovered 22 locations that they suspect were used as torture chambers in areas recently reclaimed from Russian control, a Ukrainian official said.
item.dc:creator: Oleksandr Chubko and Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Regional police investigators showed where Russian forces held and interrogated prisoners in a basement in Kozacha Lopan, in northern Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Two Russians Who Braved Miles of Open Sea and Landed on an Alaskan Island Request Asylum.
item.description: The men, apparently part of an exodus of more than 200,000 since Putin announced a new draft, traveled on a vessel from Russia and reached St. Lawrence Island in the Bering Sea.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town of Gambell on St. Lawrence Island in Alaska. Two Russians who fled from eastern Russia landed near the town on Tuesday and requested asylum, according to two U.S. senators.

item.title: Truss Meets With European Leaders, Signaling Thaw in Relations
item.description: Brexit still needs some ironing out, but Prime Minister Liz Truss’s government seems to be warming to working with Europe.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain arriving on Thursday for a meeting of the European Political Community at Prague Castle in the Czech Republic.

item.title: Student Protests on Campus Met With Violent Crackdowns in Iran
item.description: Universities across Iran have erupted in protests after more than decade of being politically dormant, with students joining the unrest that has convulsed the country for the past three weeks.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Members of Iran’s riot police were deployed on Monday on a street in Tehran.

item.title: Didier Eribon on Ernaux: She Captured ‘In One Sentence What I Couldn’t Say in a Page’
item.description: The French philosopher and sociologist said that Ernaux had always been “a great personal inspiration.”
item.dc:creator: Laura Cappelle and Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Photo by Arne Dedert/picture alliance via Getty Images
item.media:description: The French writer Didier Eribon, who also wrote about his working-class roots, said he admired Ernaux both for her writing and for her activism.

item.title: UN’s Nuclear Agency Rejects Russia’s Claim to Zaporizhzhia Plant
item.description: Russia says it is nationalizing and taking over operational control of the six-reactor plant, which its troops captured in March but which Ukrainian engineers have continued to operate.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: The director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Rafael Mariano Grossi, spoke to the news media after meeting with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: China Turns Back Move for U.N. Debate on Abuse of Uyghurs
item.description: Western countries were seeking to discuss a landmark U.N. report on China’s treatment of Uyghurs and other Muslims in the Xinjiang region.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Chinese People’s Liberation Army soldiers in China’s Xinjiang region last year.

item.title: Swedish Investigators Say Pipeline Leaks Evidence Points to Sabotage
item.description: The Swedish equivalent of the F.B.I. on Thursday confirmed the suspicion that detonations had damaged natural gas lines under the Baltic Sea.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson
item.media:credit: Danish Defence Command, via Agence France-Press — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gas leaking last week at one of the damaged Nord Stream gas pipelines in the Baltic Sea.

item.title: U.S. to Begin Screening Air Passengers From Uganda for Ebola
item.description: There are no cases in the United States, but federal health officials also urged doctors to be vigilant for patients with symptoms.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Medical personnel left an Ebola isolation section of the Mubende Regional Referral Hospital in Uganda last month.

item.title: Brittney Griner’s Wife Says They’ve Had 2 Phone Calls Since Arrest
item.description: Cherelle Griner described the second conversation with her wife, the W.N.B.A. star detained in Russia since February, as “the most disturbing phone call I’d ever experienced.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams
item.media:description: The W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner after a hearing in Khimki just outside Moscow, in August.

item.title: Two Migrant Boats Sink Off Greece; More Than 20 Believed Drowned
item.description: Rescue operations were underway for those still believed to be missing amid high winds in the Aegean Sea, the Greek Coast Guard said.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Residents looking out at floating debris after a boat carrying migrants sank off the island of Kythira on Thursday.

item.title: Mass Shootings Are Rare Outside The United States
item.description: Compared with the rest of the world, the U.S. also has far more such attacks that take place at schools.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Ivan Pierre Aguirre for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for victims of a mass shooting at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, in May. From 1966 to 2012, Americans accounted for 31 percent of the gunmen in mass shootings worldwide.

item.title: Japanese Filmmaker Toru Kubota Sentenced to 10 Years in Myanmar
item.description: A military court claimed that the 26-year-old documentarian violated immigration law and participated in protests against the regime.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Activists holding pictures of Toru Kubota during a rally in Tokyo in July.

item.title: New E.U. Sanctions Against Russia Lay Out a Cap on Oil Prices
item.description: The measures come in response to Moscow’s recent escalation of the war, and a day after global oil producers decided to cut Russia’s crude supply, increasing its value on the world market.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: Greenpeace activists placed a mock gas pipeline on the Vltava River in Prague before the European Political Community meeting there on Thursday.

item.title: Annie Ernaux Is Awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature
item.description: Ernaux’s writing has spoken particularly to women and to others who, like her, come from a working class seldom depicted with such clarity in literature.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall, Alexandra Alter, Laura Cappelle and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Isabelle Eshraghi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The French novelist Annie Ernaux in 2020.
